awd_titl_txt: Towards a Quantitative Knob for Controlling the Shape of Noble-Metal Nanocrystals
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-Technical Abstract
Controlling the shape of nanocrystals has implications that go far beyond aesthetic appeal. For nanocrystals made of precious metals such as silver, gold, palladium and platinum, the shape determines not only their physicochemical properties but also their relevance for applications in catalysis, electronics, photonics, display, sensing, medicine, environmental protection, and energy production and storage. Taking silver nanorods as an example, they can be designed with superior electrical and thermal conductivity, while having no optical absorption in the visible region, to meet the requirements for touchscreen displays, energy-efficient transparent solar films, and smart windows. The shape of a nanocrystal is determined by the twin structure and growth pattern of the seed, which are, in turn, correlated with the reduction kinetics involved in a synthesis. With the support of the Solid State and Materials Chemistry program in the Division of Materials Research, the ultimate goal of this research is to establish the role of reduction rate as a quantitative knob for manipulating the shape of nanocrystals. This research has profound impacts on the advancement of a number of disciplines by forging links between different fields, including chemistry, physics, materials science, catalysis, photonics, electronics, and energy technology. The immediate outputs of this research are advanced nanomaterials with substantially improved performance for a broad range of applications, including those related to energy production (e.g., fuel cells), protection of the environment (e.g., catalytic converters), national security, and public healthcare. The ability to produce nanocrystals of precious metals with well-controlled shapes also offers a practical strategy for achieving sustainable and prolific use of these scarce elements that only exist in the Earth's crust at a level of parts per billion. The multidisciplinary and collaborative activity greatly enhances graduate and undergraduate education and also provides a natural vehicle to promote the diversity in higher education and enrich the K-12 education.


Technical Abstract
The principal investigator will study the nucleation and growth of nanocrystals by achieving a quantitative understanding of the correlations between the reduction rate of a precursor and the number of twin defects in a seed, as well as its growth pattern. Using palladium as a model system, the research team will develop spectroscopy methods to determine the kinetic parameters (including rate constant and activation energy) of various reduction reactions used for nanocrystal synthesis and then determine the range of reduction rates responsible for the formation of a specific type of seeds characterized by a single-crystal, singly-twinned, multiply-twinned, or stacking-fault-lined structure. The kinetic parameters will also be applied to analyze the growth patterns of cubic and decahedral seeds (with single-crystal and five-fold twinned structures, respectively) in an effort to achieve a deep understanding of new phenomena such as symmetry breaking or reduction. As a powerful demonstration, the quantitative knowledge about the effects of reduction rate on the nucleation and growth of seeds will be further applied to design synthetic protocols for the production of silver nanorods with no optical absorption in the entire visible region by working with palladium decahedral seeds smaller than 20 nm. Taken together, this research will bring major advances to the field of nanotechnology by unraveling the essential knowledge and design rule for the deterministic syntheses of nanocrystals with well-controlled shapes and related properties central to a broad range of fundamental studies and industrially important applications.

por.por_cntn:
This research has brought major advances to the field of nanotechnology by unraveling the essential knowledge and design rule for the predictable and deterministic synthesis of colloidal metal nanocrystals with controlled shapes and related properties that are pivotal to a range of fundamental studies and industrially important applications. A number of breakthroughs were made. One of the studies addressed a long-standing major problem in the colloidal synthesis of metal nanocrystals, that is, how is the precursor reduced to the elemental form for the incorporation into growing nanocrystals? In principle, the precursor can be reduced to an atom in the solution phase, followed by its deposition onto the surface of a nanocrystal. Alternatively, the precursor can adsorb onto the surface of a nanocrystal, followed by reduction through an autocatalytic process. Kinetic analysis indicated that the reduction pathway had a strong dependence on the reduction rate of the precursor. At a fast rate, the precursor was reduced in the solution phase, leading to additional homogeneous nucleation and growth. At a slow rate, in contrast, the precursor was reduced on the surface of a nanocrystal through adsorption and then autocatalytic reduction. This latter pathway did not involve homogeneous nucleation, resulting in growth only. When the reaction temperature was increased, this was a clear transition from surface reduction to solution reduction. The reduction kinetics were also applied to analyze the growth patterns of cubic and decahedral seeds (with single-crystal and five-fold twinned structures, respectively) for the realization of a deep understanding of the symmetry breaking phenomenon. The quantitative knowledge about the effects of reduction kinetics on the nucleation and growth of seeds was further utilized to rationally design a protocol for the synthesis of silver nanorods with no optical absorption in the visible region by working with palladium decahedral seeds smaller than 20 nm. Such nanorods are anticipated to find use in the fabrication of conductive, transparent, and flexible electrodes sought for touchscreen applications. The new findings were documented in 35 original research publications, 15 invited review articles, and more than 100 invited talks.

This research has profound impacts on the advancement of a number of disciplines by forging links between chemistry, physics, materials science, and chemical engineering in the context of catalysis, photonics, electronics, and energy technology. The major products of this project are advanced nanomaterials with substantially improved performance in a broad range of applications, including those related to energy conversion, environmental protection, national security, and public healthcare. The ability to produce nanocrystals of precious metals with controlled shapes also offers a practical strategy for achieving cost-effective and sustainable use of these scarce elements that only exist in the Earth's crust at a level of parts per billion. The multidisciplinary and collaborative activities have greatly enhanced graduate and undergraduate education while providing a natural vehicle to promote diversity in higher education and enrich K-12 education. This project partially supported the training of 10 graduate students, and eight of them (including two Hispanic females) have received their Ph.D. degrees. It also engaged one high school female student, four undergraduate students from Georgia Tech (two males and two females), and six REU students (three females, one African American female, and one Hispanic) for conducting summer research. As a result of their significant contributions, these undergraduate students co-authored six publications.
